reviewText: Having finished the game before on PS3, I feel qualified to say that, for all intents and purposes, this is a pretty decent port of the game that all Final Fantasy fans should try. I'm not going to give my opinion of the game in detail but I will say that it is very underrated and, if nothing else, worth experiencing at this price for the visuals and audio alone. Square Enix is truly in a class of their own when it comes to audio/visual design and FFXIII is one of the best places to see it until XV is released. This new port of the game is optimized to run at 60 frames per second, maximum, though you might have a hard time hitting that consistently if your system isn't configured properly. By enabling Vsync through my GPU drivers for this game, forcing Anisotropic Filtering (which is unrelated but really helps the visuals), and setting my PC to Maximum Performance in the power settings I was able to get 60fps at almost all times during battle and field scenes, though cutscenes (especially the pre-rendered ones of course) tended to hover around 30fps, which is fine.\n\nIn general, if you were ever interested in this game and are very easily swayed by gorgeous, artistic visuals and sound, you will enjoy this game, especially at a discount like this. The Japanese dual audio option also helps if you find the English voices grating on your ears, which is subjective; I'm fine with them but options are always nice! It's true that, at the moment, the game is locked at 720p and you use the ESC key to quit the game, but those are not nearly as big of a deal as they're made out to be as long as your GPU or monitor properly scales the game to your screen size. The game uses a lot of post-processing effects so that the 720p visuals are barely noticeable on my 1080p screen except for occasional aliasing, and the game runs so smoothly with those small tweaks that I barely notice anything wrong" with how the game looks anyway. In the end

reviewText:
I had no technical problems with this game it runs fine.  The combat and mechanics are fine if a bit over top cartoony.

I wanted to like this game and played all the way through but in the end I have to just describe it as bad.  The problem is, if you are going to have a linear story based game then the story needs to make sense and be interesting.  The plot in this game is literally the main characters wandering around never knowining what to do next.  After having no clue what is happening the whole time, the evil bosses then give cliched speeches telling the heroes what to do next.  It is truely awful.

This isnt just bad translation or acting.  The characters actually endlessly discuss that they never know what to do next.  That is the plot.   Square literally has no idea how to write a plot and dialogue that makes any sense for them to follow.  This is really to bad because alot of other things about the game are great.  The characters themselves are fairly interesting and the English voice acting is actually top notch making me want to like the characters.  The actual plot and sequence of events is just eyerolling and unforgivable.

If anyone is totally new to the Final Fantasy games, get Final Fantasy 10 in the bargain bin instead of this one.  It is better in just about every way imaginable with a story that actually makes some sense.  It is the difference between This is our story..." and what story?"

You think previous Final Fantasy games were linear? You thought FFX was linear? At least those games gave you the illusion of choice and had nice scenery.

Even 13 euro is too much for this game. 5 euro tops."

reviewText:
Just a warning to anyone looking to buy this game. TLDR - Horrible porting job.

There are no graphical settings. You are locked in to 720p and have no control over texture quality, antialiasing  or anything else. You can use GeDoSaTo to get around this, which will allow you to get the resolution up, but it has no effect on the pre-rendered cut scenes (of which there are plenty).

The game couldn't tell the difference between a 360 controller and a joystick, wouldn't let me choose, and refused to accept the latter's input until the former had been unplugged.

It's a good thing that the save points are so close together, because pressing escape will immediately  exit the game. No warnings. Straight to desktop. Why did they bind the ragequit button to one that is normally used to exit a menu?!?

Don't expect to alt-tab either. And attempt to minimise the game will make it crash. If you're unlucky enough to have something minimise the game (add new hardware wizard, I'm looking at you!) you're going to be re-loading your save from the most recent point.

If the one-man team behind 'From Dust' can do an awesome PC Port, I don't see why Square Enix can't. Not worth the money in it's current state.

reviewText:
My opinion of the Final Fantasy 13 trilogy.

Now this isn't a little kid review unlike most the reviews already posted. If you play for graphics, you aren't a gamer and should uninstall steam.

Alright, this is going to be lengthy. Since most haters can't put up arguments on why this game is bad, here's my good/bad. Overall i'd give this game a 7/10.

Good things I liked about Final Fantasy 13 was the side quests(all 64 of them), the paradom(paradime? forgot the systems name), memorible characters and the fact they added more to the story.

Game had difficulty, specailly first bartandualus fight(don't know how to spell that face gods name), the summon things that come out when they face themselves were no pushovers and the star rank rating system was amusing, good way to test out your skill.

Bad things I don't like is the AMOUNT of cutscenes they have, its like MGS4, they focused too much on the story. The footsteps were also very loud, annoyed me through most of the game. The villians were also meh, didn't really like them all too much. I forgot them fairly quick.

The game did much better in 13-2 by allowing EVERY area you've been to be explored again. Required a lot of back tracking to get through the game. Even had a difficulty level in case you thought the game was too hard or too easy. The main villian was great, very memorble.

Lightning returns story was bleh at best, but I LOVED the action RPG combat it had. Not to mention you could explore EVERYTHING in that game. Requires a lot of side quests to be able to finish the 5 bosses(6, not sure cause of hidden boss on the 13th day). The villian was bloody terrible, bad writing too.

I'd recommend it for RPG lovers, not for casual gamers however.

I have no problem recommending this game as a Steam Sale grab.

reviewText:
The game itself is not bad. I played it on PS3 way back when. However, this game has so many problems on pc! This game only uses one core of your cpu making the framerate drop seemingly out of nowhere. It runs at 720p natively and you can't change it. It has no graphics options to speak of. It has no audio options to speak of. And on top of all that, if you just so happen to have an amd cpu the game sill be locked at 30 fps.

To everyone thinking about buying this: DON'T! At least not until they patch it.

If you really want the game but don't want to deal with any of this there is a petition to get Square to fix the game.

Go here and sign the petition: http://www.change.org/p/final-fantasy-13-pc-version-1920x1080-and-graphic-options-give-the-pc-version-of-final-fantasy-13-the-ability-to-change-graphical-settings

PS: The reason why the game is a 50 gig download is because they automatically include the japanese audio. You don't even have a choice to download it!

PPS: There is no real way to quit the game in ANY menu. You literally have to hit escape and the game instantly stops. No  Are you sure you want to quit?" It just ends!

reviewText:
Just a warning to anyone looking to buy this game. TLDR - Horrible porting job.

There are no graphical settings. You are locked in to 720p and have no control over texture quality, antialiasing  or anything else. You can use GeDoSaTo to get around this, which will allow you to get the resolution up, but it has no effect on the pre-rendered cut scenes (of which there are plenty).

The game couldn't tell the difference between a 360 controller and a joystick, wouldn't let me choose, and refused to accept the latter's input until the former had been unplugged.

It's a good thing that the save points are so close together, because pressing escape will immediately  exit the game. No warnings. Straight to desktop. Why did they bind the ragequit button to one that is normally used to exit a menu?!?

Don't expect to alt-tab either. And attempt to minimise the game will make it crash. If you're unlucky enough to have something minimise the game (add new hardware wizard, I'm looking at you!) you're going to be re-loading your save from the most recent point.

If the one-man team behind 'From Dust' can do an awesome PC Port, I don't see why Square Enix can't. Not worth the money in it's current state.

reviewText:
First for those that HAVE played the game before, the game is 60gb of awful as a straight port.  That said, the game looks amazing with the Durante fix that I'm sure you can find easily by googling.  FPS suffers a bit but not much with the patch, but does drop every now and then, but not enough to ruin the experience (for me at least).   Also, just to put this out there, the alt-tab issue is fixed with the patch, the steam overlay seems to slow down significantly, and hitting escape will still exit the game immediately.

For those that HAVEN'T played the game before, DO NOT BUY THIS IF YOU'RE LOOKING FOR AN RPG.  Exploration is near non-existent, you have only a slight choice in building your characters, and during the 'tutorial' that lasts what seems like half the game, you don't even have control over your party as a whole.  There's only slight differences in the stats and abilities of all characters that you will have control over once everyone is fully built.

On the good side, however, i really enjoy the music and gameplay.   This is one of my favorite FF piano soundtracks, and even though it's not a true RPG, the gameplay is fast paced and does require a small degree of strategy (a little more so on the 'bosses').  The graphics deserve special mention as they are amazing.  Once again, you realy need the fix because the default steam version looks AWFUL compared to even the xbox's version.  And the story... oh the story... It has so much potential and is just a convoluted mess.   And don't get me started on the characters.  This may be a shoo-in for having at least some of the most shallow FF characters of all time, and easily has one of the most annoying.

So do I recommend it? Yep.  Just make sure you know what you're getting yourself into though!

reviewText:
Final Fantasy is my favorite game series of all time, I grew up playing one and only one game, Final Fantasy X, which is my favorite game of all time. I have played a couple of other FF games but once you play X or XIII it is hard to go back to the older ones. Final Fantasy lived up to my hopes that it would be comparable to X. While many people complain about the linearity of the game and the limit to exploration, I think it is fine. When I played this game I played it for the story, which is possibly my favorite story of any game I have ever played, all of the characters are unique and pull you into the story. I originally played this game on Xbox 360 and bought it on PC when it came out. While the PC port is sort of lazy, but they have improved it greatly. Compared to the Xbox version the graphics look incredible and really show how beautiful this game is. The soundtrack is one of the best I have heard and I love all of the songs and the scenes that they correspond to. The visuals in the game are gorgeous and the CGI cut scenes are so realistic and incredibly good looking. There are about 7 hours of cut scenes on their own. The sequels to this game are also similar, they have great stories and even better, more polished gameplay. The combat system works well and is very fun. End game there is plenty to do if you are one who likes farming to get the best gear and clearing all of the missions and objectives. I absolutely love this game and it will definitely play with your emotions and make you want to keep playing. This is in my Top 5 games of all time.

Pros:
- Incredible story that has many plot twists and changes
- Very developed and unique characters
- Decent replayability with farming and gear
- Great visuals
- Stunning cutscenes
- Great Soundtrack
- long story (30-35 hours)

Cons:
- Linear story
- Below average port

2/10

reviewText:
As a long time huge Final Fantasy fan, this is very hard for me, and I don't think there is really any correct way for somebody to write a review on this game. Whether you like it or dislike it, there will always be a large number of people waiting to hate you for it. But I'll share my thoughts at least:
I personally feel like 9 or 10 was the last true Final Fantasy game, then the world map disappeared, the battle system changed repeatedly, and of course, most areas became boring corridors in FF13.
I wasn't a big fan of 12, but it was still fine, and so far (about half way through the game, I think), I dislike 13 more than any other Final Fantasy that has come before it. However, my thoughts continue to change on it as I get further...

I started off very unimpressed by the boring areas, lack of exploration, annoying characters (or lack of personality, in Lightning's case), and I hated the battle system. I always enjoyed strategically giving commands to all my characters individually, but in this game, you only control the leader, and pretty much just give suggestions to the other party members. Granted, they're actually quite smart sometimes, but I just feel like I would be a lot more comfortable knowing exactly what everybody is going to do.

But as I got further, I started to accept things a bit more. The battle system is quite clever in some ways, the areas start to get slightly more interesting (I think), and despite what people say, there is actually some character development. I never thought I'd say it, but I've warmed up to the game, and even Lightning's character.
But at the same time, I think this is still my least favourite Final Fantasy (I've not played any other game in the FF13 trilogy yet). In fact, it's probably one of my least favourite JRPGs in general. And yet, I feel like the good parts are so good that it's still enjoyable and worth my time.

Anyway, I'm far from an experienced reviewer or anything, but to anybody on the fence about whether or not to try this game, I'd say:
Give it a go, but be patient with it. There were times when I just wanted to stop playing and give up on it, but I've continued onward and am enjoying it more than expected, for the most part. Give the characters a chance, even at their most obnoxious and whiny. They become more bearable, at least to me.

And that's about all I can think of to say about this game. I hope it helped in any way at all, but if not, oh well... I'm just sharing my opinion online, leave me alone!  D:

reviewText:
Final Fantasy XIII is not a good Final Fantasy, but it's a really fun and gorgeous JRPG.

The story follows two different worlds: Pulse and Cacoon, each so afraid of the others that even contact with someone from the other planet will cause friends and family to turn against each other in order to rid themselves of those affected. Ruled by benevloent creatures called fal'Cie, players follow a commando, Lightning, and the people she meets as they are touched and turned into l'Cie, or touched warriors, by a Pulse fal'Cie that had hidden on Cacoon for ages.

The combat system features some FF staples such as Phoenix Downs, summons, and certain magics, but instead of picking abilities individually, most players will likely be auto-attacking. Instead, the challenge comes from its Role system, or Paradigms. Paradigms are customized for each party, and rather than selecting attacks, players will be juggling roles among their characters fairly heavily. The result is a little different from other FFs, but it's fast-paced, pretty fun, and can get fairly difficult if role combinations don't pit well against tougher fights. Characters can then be leveled up by putting points into their various roles.

Perhaps the biggest criticism with the game comes from the exploration, as this is where XIII splits from previous titles. Instead of an open world environment, players are set along linear paths with little room to move about. There are no World Maps, airships to control, or forests filled with random battles to get lost in. It feels nothing like Final Fantasies in that that regard.

However, franchise name aside, the maps tend to work. Most jRPGs are simply Go From Point A to Point B" to begin with

I said I would repost after playing the game. I can't comment on the patches because my system (stats follow) handled the game beautifully. The only times I missed 1080p (versus the 720p fullscreen) on a decent 42' screen was when I missed antialiasing/anistropic filtering settings. Basically if you pay too much attention to other characters on the map, you may see edges that aren't exactly smooth.

MY RATING: That said, I give this game 9/10, considering it's an FF jRPG classic and the graphics are amazing and the port is really good.

DISMISSAL OF GRAPHICS WHINERS WITHOUT APPROPRIATE HARDWARE: As I said before, I'm a software developer, and, using my knowledge of code and now experience with the game, I don't think the character models, textures, etc. need any updating to 1080p. Instead, let folks add AA and such, if they can't already get that through their graphics driver. It would ruin the original graphics, imho! I heard someone complain that the computer got the lesser quality cutscenes, but 50GB is enough for a game, imho, and, again, this is the definitive modern jRPG non-MMO graphically and otherwise as far as I'm concerned.

SUMMARY: So, that done, on to the summary of the game: be prepared to not understand the story or how combat works completely for 4-8 hours, depending on the speed you play jRPGs. But this game delivers in length- not quite as long as I'd wish in a perfect world, but, being completionist, it took me at least 120hrs to get through. You can handle that, as the crazy FF fan who can't choose between FF, FFIII, FFIV, and FFVI for the best FF, right? FFVII was great, no question, but not in the running... kind of like FFX.

reviewText:
Having played this game on Xbox 360, I can say I am happy to own it on PC now as well. I thoroughly enjoyed the game and I don't undertand what is so confusing about the story to people. At this point, I think it is just a fad to call this story confusing. Sure some of the charatcers seem a little flat and aren't lovable, but they grow on you in different ways. Definitely by far, Hope has the most character development and becomes one of my favorites story-wise by the end of the game.

Enough about the story though, let's talk about the port. So far (Although I haven't played it much yet) I have not run into a single bug, runs just as smooth as you would expect from a Square Enix game. the 60fps is definitely noticable having played it at a now considerably less smooth 30fps on console. The anti-aliasing is also a great touch going all the way up to 16x to wipe away the jaggies that 7th gen console games are known for. Having not actually changed the textures of the game (which still look fine for 2014), don't worry about raising the settings and experiencing lag because as long as you meet the recommended, pump up that AA. The shadows resolution goes all the way up to 8k creating crisp player shadows suring fights and walking around. And last but not least, being able to run this game natively 1080p is a dream come true. Given the astonishing beauty of this game even on console, a 1080p version of it makes it all the better and really turns this game into a piece of art.

Now as for cons, just wish that they would have tweaked the gameplay just a bit like the camera control which is still god-awful. All it wants to do is reset back to center. Might as well have a fixed camera. I would have liked better camera control to admire the beautiful scenery this game has to offer. Also speeding up the gameplay such as making paradigm shifts smoother like in XIII-2 would have been nice. Instead you have the long drawn-out shifts. Also I would have liked to see them up the amount of Gil you get from treasure chests or maybe throw in Gil when you win a battle. Gil shortage was a huge problem in the console version and required endless hours of Trapezohedron and Plat ingot hunting to get enough to get everyone's final weapons. On console, I put about 120 hrs into a single playthrough of this game and probably more than 20 of it was grinding for money... This game was obviously a copy and paste port, but at the price point, can't blame them.

Given there are no bugs so far and the game looks better and plays just as well as on console, I give the port a 9/10 and the game a 8/10. For a final fantasy game story wise, 7.5/10.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy XIII is still one of my favourites in the FF series that I've played so far of X and XII and multiple Crystal Chronicle games. It's combat style is quick paced and interesting to watch but can unfortunately become a tedious mash of auto battle unless you are looking for the best strategies to consistantly 5 star your fights and boss battles in epic strategic frustration.

It's story is based mostly on the development of characters' morals and their reason to keep on fighting" but other than that we are left quite in the dark about the history of Cocoon and Gran Pulse which would have been amazing to flesh out and bring to life within the game. I have yet to finish FF XIII-2 or play Lightning Returns to see how the world fleshes out but it is an interesting and exciting universe.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy XIII is not a good Final Fantasy, but it's a really fun and gorgeous JRPG.

The story follows two different worlds: Pulse and Cacoon, each so afraid of the others that even contact with someone from the other planet will cause friends and family to turn against each other in order to rid themselves of those affected. Ruled by benevloent creatures called fal'Cie, players follow a commando, Lightning, and the people she meets as they are touched and turned into l'Cie, or touched warriors, by a Pulse fal'Cie that had hidden on Cacoon for ages.

The combat system features some FF staples such as Phoenix Downs, summons, and certain magics, but instead of picking abilities individually, most players will likely be auto-attacking. Instead, the challenge comes from its Role system, or Paradigms. Paradigms are customized for each party, and rather than selecting attacks, players will be juggling roles among their characters fairly heavily. The result is a little different from other FFs, but it's fast-paced, pretty fun, and can get fairly difficult if role combinations don't pit well against tougher fights. Characters can then be leveled up by putting points into their various roles.

Perhaps the biggest criticism with the game comes from the exploration, as this is where XIII splits from previous titles. Instead of an open world environment, players are set along linear paths with little room to move about. There are no World Maps, airships to control, or forests filled with random battles to get lost in. It feels nothing like Final Fantasies in that that regard.

However, franchise name aside, the maps tend to work. Most jRPGs are simply Go From Point A to Point B" to begin with

reviewText:
Having played this game on Xbox 360, I can say I am happy to own it on PC now as well. I thoroughly enjoyed the game and I don't undertand what is so confusing about the story to people. At this point, I think it is just a fad to call this story confusing. Sure some of the charatcers seem a little flat and aren't lovable, but they grow on you in different ways. Definitely by far, Hope has the most character development and becomes one of my favorites story-wise by the end of the game.

Enough about the story though, let's talk about the port. So far (Although I haven't played it much yet) I have not run into a single bug, runs just as smooth as you would expect from a Square Enix game. the 60fps is definitely noticable having played it at a now considerably less smooth 30fps on console. The anti-aliasing is also a great touch going all the way up to 16x to wipe away the jaggies that 7th gen console games are known for. Having not actually changed the textures of the game (which still look fine for 2014), don't worry about raising the settings and experiencing lag because as long as you meet the recommended, pump up that AA. The shadows resolution goes all the way up to 8k creating crisp player shadows suring fights and walking around. And last but not least, being able to run this game natively 1080p is a dream come true. Given the astonishing beauty of this game even on console, a 1080p version of it makes it all the better and really turns this game into a piece of art.

Now as for cons, just wish that they would have tweaked the gameplay just a bit like the camera control which is still god-awful. All it wants to do is reset back to center. Might as well have a fixed camera. I would have liked better camera control to admire the beautiful scenery this game has to offer. Also speeding up the gameplay such as making paradigm shifts smoother like in XIII-2 would have been nice. Instead you have the long drawn-out shifts. Also I would have liked to see them up the amount of Gil you get from treasure chests or maybe throw in Gil when you win a battle. Gil shortage was a huge problem in the console version and required endless hours of Trapezohedron and Plat ingot hunting to get enough to get everyone's final weapons. On console, I put about 120 hrs into a single playthrough of this game and probably more than 20 of it was grinding for money... This game was obviously a copy and paste port, but at the price point, can't blame them.

Given there are no bugs so far and the game looks better and plays just as well as on console, I give the port a 9/10 and the game a 8/10. For a final fantasy game story wise, 7.5/10.

reviewText:
Aah~~ FFXIII.....the game everyone either loves or hates.
This game is definitely not for everyone, however you should still enjoy it if you're a huge FF fan.
The game is hugely linear,especially the first 20~30 hours,however the game does open up a little towards the end,though not by much. If you know you're not the kind of person that can handle linearity, do not pick up this title. The game has 13 Chapters, however the game only opens up at Chapter 11. Chapter 1~10 is all about getting used to the battle system and all about the storytelling.The world is really greatly thought out with some really great visuals. Masahi Hamauzu also did a great job with the soundtracks, following in the footsteps of Nobuo Uematsu.The soundtrack is simply awesome.
The story and characters are basically FF. Many people say the story is too convoluted, however if you follow the game's pacing everything will be handed on a plate, overall not a bad storyline.The characters are quite interesting and there are rooms for character development.
The battle system is quite different in a way it is really fast and frantic. It would seem like full-on buttle mashing but it has a lot of interesting approaches to a battle.The battle system is still a love or hate relationship, if you're considering this title, check up some gameplay on the Internet first.
Overall, I do enjoy this title and will recommend it to diehard FF fans. For gamers new to the series however, I strongly advise you to do extensive research before picking up. The game is still great but it may not be your taste. You have been warned.

reviewText:
Having played Final Fantasy XIII on the PS3 twice, I decided to purchase the game once again, this time for Steam. The game will take up a big amount of GB, around 50. Yes, that is much, because of the many cutscenes this game has. The game has a good and interesting story, maybe a bit confusing at times if you don't pay attention, but luckily, you can reread all of it in the game itself; so if you take a break from playing the game, coming back to it later and don't know what's going on, it's easy getting back into.
The battle system is pretty cool. You can only control one character in battle, but that's not a bad thing, since the battles are still pretty busy when you're fighting enemies.
It is true that you don't have a lot of freedom in the game when it comes to exploration, it is pretty linear, but on the other side, it gives the story enough time to unfold itself.
The characters are all individual; one is funny, the other one may be more serious, etc. I'm sure you'll find someone you like. My personal favorite is Lightning.
All in all, I like the approach that this game in the Final Fantasy series is taking. Alot of times, people complain about that games and their sequels are too similar, so why not change something once in a while?
I hope you have as much fun with this game like me.

reviewText:
Just finished this thing. Good combat, good art style, bad pacing, bad level design, bad story, bad characters.

By far the best combat I've run into in a Final Fantasy game (I absolutely loved the Paradigm system), but there's just too much of it. This game consists of about 50 hours worth of hallways with a meaningless throwaway battle every ten steps.

It briefly breaks out of the hallways around the 25-hour mark, opening up the game a bunch and giving you an opportunity to do more meaningless combat until you've leveled up enough to continue. Once you've done a sufficient amount of grinding, it's back to the hallways.

The characters weren't interesting. Out of six characters, only two of them were even believable as human beings. The rest were hamfisted caricatures that seemed to be written by a checklist.   The two person-esque characters still weren't anything special.

One of the characters is a scantily-clad 14-year-old girl who moans, sighs, and grunts sexually, nonstop, in every single cutscene. If you weren't watching the cutscenes, it would have you convinced that someone was having sex in the background of every single cutscene she's in.

The story is nonsensical. It meanders tediously, relying entirely on the characters inexplicably wandering to places they have no reason to go to. Over and over and over. Repeat until, all in one cutscene, each and every major plot point gets abruptly and miraculously tied up without any explanations for how these miracles happened.

Deeply unsatisfying.

reviewText:
First for those that HAVE played the game before, the game is 60gb of awful as a straight port.  That said, the game looks amazing with the Durante fix that I'm sure you can find easily by googling.  FPS suffers a bit but not much with the patch, but does drop every now and then, but not enough to ruin the experience (for me at least).   Also, just to put this out there, the alt-tab issue is fixed with the patch, the steam overlay seems to slow down significantly, and hitting escape will still exit the game immediately.

For those that HAVEN'T played the game before, DO NOT BUY THIS IF YOU'RE LOOKING FOR AN RPG.  Exploration is near non-existent, you have only a slight choice in building your characters, and during the 'tutorial' that lasts what seems like half the game, you don't even have control over your party as a whole.  There's only slight differences in the stats and abilities of all characters that you will have control over once everyone is fully built.

On the good side, however, i really enjoy the music and gameplay.   This is one of my favorite FF piano soundtracks, and even though it's not a true RPG, the gameplay is fast paced and does require a small degree of strategy (a little more so on the 'bosses').  The graphics deserve special mention as they are amazing.  Once again, you realy need the fix because the default steam version looks AWFUL compared to even the xbox's version.  And the story... oh the story... It has so much potential and is just a convoluted mess.   And don't get me started on the characters.  This may be a shoo-in for having at least some of the most shallow FF characters of all time, and easily has one of the most annoying.

So do I recommend it? Yep.  Just make sure you know what you're getting yourself into though!

reviewText:
I'm nearly done with my first playthrough and the flaws are poking at me with very sharp sticks. But the good parts are sparkly and great.

I was a little skeptical when I decided to buy the game. I spent at least a week poring over the reviews before I actually bought the review. All of them give the same message : You MIGHT like this game. Good luck.

Basically, the big issue I had was with how tedious some of the gameplay felt. Other than that, it was actually a really great game, with pretty graphics, not-boring (though somewhat confusing and cliche) plot, and a lovely battle system.

The Plot:
Just keep running. Just... keep running. Run through monsters. Crush them under your boots, and keep running. Run around them. Sneakily steal loot from treasure orb-chest-things while guarding mob isn't looking. Have issues with your party running away from you or you running away from them like twenty times before reuniting AND STAYING THAT WAY.

Then slap the living daylights out of everything while trying to figure out what you're gonna do with the time you have left. You have like a dozen chapters to figure it out and even near the end you got some issues.

The Verdict:
I need a lot of CS. Therefore I must grind.
I need a lot of gil. Therefore I must grind.
I need equipment. Therefore I must get gil. Therefore I must grind.

Yeah, at this point I'm gonna put down the controller and take a break. Probably play something else then come back and grind intensely.

The slight tediousness is what kills the experience a little. The battle system is fun, but of course too much of a good thing gets tiring. Until you get the freedom to rearrange your party, around chapter 10 and 11, the whole game feels like a very, very long tutorial. It's great because the monsters are little weak babies, but then whammo you fall out of the sky into Pulse and there's Behemoths in pairs and giant turtoises dominating the plains. Whee. More running.

I loved it at first, then slowly got kinda tired of it. I'll grow to love it again, but then the cycle'll keep going.

So yeah, fair warning about buying it.

reviewText:
As a long time huge Final Fantasy fan, this is very hard for me, and I don't think there is really any correct way for somebody to write a review on this game. Whether you like it or dislike it, there will always be a large number of people waiting to hate you for it. But I'll share my thoughts at least:
I personally feel like 9 or 10 was the last true Final Fantasy game, then the world map disappeared, the battle system changed repeatedly, and of course, most areas became boring corridors in FF13.
I wasn't a big fan of 12, but it was still fine, and so far (about half way through the game, I think), I dislike 13 more than any other Final Fantasy that has come before it. However, my thoughts continue to change on it as I get further...

I started off very unimpressed by the boring areas, lack of exploration, annoying characters (or lack of personality, in Lightning's case), and I hated the battle system. I always enjoyed strategically giving commands to all my characters individually, but in this game, you only control the leader, and pretty much just give suggestions to the other party members. Granted, they're actually quite smart sometimes, but I just feel like I would be a lot more comfortable knowing exactly what everybody is going to do.

But as I got further, I started to accept things a bit more. The battle system is quite clever in some ways, the areas start to get slightly more interesting (I think), and despite what people say, there is actually some character development. I never thought I'd say it, but I've warmed up to the game, and even Lightning's character.
But at the same time, I think this is still my least favourite Final Fantasy (I've not played any other game in the FF13 trilogy yet). In fact, it's probably one of my least favourite JRPGs in general. And yet, I feel like the good parts are so good that it's still enjoyable and worth my time.

Anyway, I'm far from an experienced reviewer or anything, but to anybody on the fence about whether or not to try this game, I'd say:
Give it a go, but be patient with it. There were times when I just wanted to stop playing and give up on it, but I've continued onward and am enjoying it more than expected, for the most part. Give the characters a chance, even at their most obnoxious and whiny. They become more bearable, at least to me.

And that's about all I can think of to say about this game. I hope it helped in any way at all, but if not, oh well... I'm just sharing my opinion online, leave me alone!  D:

reviewText:
Final Fantasy is my favorite game series of all time, I grew up playing one and only one game, Final Fantasy X, which is my favorite game of all time. I have played a couple of other FF games but once you play X or XIII it is hard to go back to the older ones. Final Fantasy lived up to my hopes that it would be comparable to X. While many people complain about the linearity of the game and the limit to exploration, I think it is fine. When I played this game I played it for the story, which is possibly my favorite story of any game I have ever played, all of the characters are unique and pull you into the story. I originally played this game on Xbox 360 and bought it on PC when it came out. While the PC port is sort of lazy, but they have improved it greatly. Compared to the Xbox version the graphics look incredible and really show how beautiful this game is. The soundtrack is one of the best I have heard and I love all of the songs and the scenes that they correspond to. The visuals in the game are gorgeous and the CGI cut scenes are so realistic and incredibly good looking. There are about 7 hours of cut scenes on their own. The sequels to this game are also similar, they have great stories and even better, more polished gameplay. The combat system works well and is very fun. End game there is plenty to do if you are one who likes farming to get the best gear and clearing all of the missions and objectives. I absolutely love this game and it will definitely play with your emotions and make you want to keep playing. This is in my Top 5 games of all time.

Pros:
- Incredible story that has many plot twists and changes
- Very developed and unique characters
- Decent replayability with farming and gear
- Great visuals
- Stunning cutscenes
- Great Soundtrack
- long story (30-35 hours)

Cons:
- Linear story
- Below average port

reviewText:
Final Fantasy XIII (13) - PC Port Review by RetriButioN

Port Quality: 4/10

Final Fantasy XIII was originally a console exclusive title like most of the titles in the FF series, however 13 and some other Final Fantasy games have been recently ported to PC along with some other old-school JRGPs like Valkyria Chronicles.
Unfortunately the quality of port is much below expectation, even though it has been patched several times it still has some serious flaws. Performance is terrible even on most powerful PCs although this game is several years old. The engine also stutters every few seconds if you don't plug-in a controller or use a virtual (fake) one. Also the game provides very little graphic customization options.
Being a very bad port is the only downside of this game. Final Fantasy XIII is one of the best JRPG titles ever released and has won several awards. If you manage to get over the troubled shell, you will find a beautiful gem inside.

Gameplay: 9/10

Gameplay structure is a bit different than most RPG & JRPG titles available on the market. Most of your playtime will be spent battling various monsters and enemies through game's innovative battle system called ATB (Active Time Battle). ATB is closer to Turn-Based gameplay of traditional JRPG games rather than Real-Time. Your party consists of two or three characters, of which only the leader can be controlled. The rest of your party is controlled by AI which does a pretty good job.
The progression speed of the game is very slow which can frustrate impatient and casual players. Game takes a very long time to unlocks all of its gameplay features. It's basically like a very long tutorial that makes up for almost half of your playtime before showing you the true game. Final Fantasy 13 is mostly linear with paths filled with enemies and a cut-scene at the end.
Overall, gameplay is very addictive and rewarding. It's a difficult game to fully accomplish and some of the optional bosses and enemies need a lot of grinding to defeat.

Story & Lore: 10/10

Story is where Final Fantasy titles shine, Final Fantasy 13 is no exception. It has a very expansive lore and a really intriguing story. Although it may be a little hard to grasp for newcomers, it's what you would remember for a long time once you understand its true nature. Characters are presented in a very good way and as they develop, story becomes more and more interesting.
Final Fantasy 13 is like a living, breathing world that you can live in.

Visuals & Graphics: 8/10

The original game is a relatively old title so we can't except cutting-edge technology and mind-blowing visuals. However, the art design of the game is simply fantastic. As with most Japanese titles, a lot of work has been put into art design. Every single monster you encounter looks alive, every single character you see look real. The world is very beautiful.
Unfortunately, the technical aspect of the game and its weak engine can't really catch up with today's standards but the art design can easily make up for it.

Audio & Music: 10/10

Again, another area in which Final Fantasy titles have always been great is music. Soundtrack is amazing and you feel like you want to listen to it over and over again. Sound Effects are great too and Voice Acting is professional. Both Japanese and English voice actors should be proud of their work.

Overall Score (Conclusion): 7.5/10

Final Fantasy 13 is one of the best JRPG games that I've ever played, however the PC port feels very rushed and is done terribly. It still doesn't make the game itself a bad title, but the PC release is really a weak port. I'd recommend getting it on the console if you haven't played it already (and own a console, of course) but if you don't have a console, well PC seems to be your only choice.

reviewText:
Just finished this thing. Good combat, good art style, bad pacing, bad level design, bad story, bad characters.

By far the best combat I've run into in a Final Fantasy game (I absolutely loved the Paradigm system), but there's just too much of it. This game consists of about 50 hours worth of hallways with a meaningless throwaway battle every ten steps.

It briefly breaks out of the hallways around the 25-hour mark, opening up the game a bunch and giving you an opportunity to do more meaningless combat until you've leveled up enough to continue. Once you've done a sufficient amount of grinding, it's back to the hallways.

The characters weren't interesting. Out of six characters, only two of them were even believable as human beings. The rest were hamfisted caricatures that seemed to be written by a checklist.   The two person-esque characters still weren't anything special.

One of the characters is a scantily-clad 14-year-old girl who moans, sighs, and grunts sexually, nonstop, in every single cutscene. If you weren't watching the cutscenes, it would have you convinced that someone was having sex in the background of every single cutscene she's in.

The story is nonsensical. It meanders tediously, relying entirely on the characters inexplicably wandering to places they have no reason to go to. Over and over and over. Repeat until, all in one cutscene, each and every major plot point gets abruptly and miraculously tied up without any explanations for how these miracles happened.

Deeply unsatisfying.

reviewText: The game play is fast paced and somewhat entertaining with it's combo autobattle system. Though after a almost 2 hours of playing I realized all i was doing was hitting 1 button fast while in combat and then using a potion as needed every 9 or 10 fights. This I can look past since final fantasy games for me has always been more about the story that pulls you in and the sense of accomplishment you get when you overcome the various hurdles thrown in your path for character development. This game failed miserably in providing either one of those.\nThis game has you change main characters every 15 to 25 minutes during the first few hours of play. There is no depth, it's full of cliches, and lacks from any sense of cohesion that could possibly be existant in a storyline except for the fact that there is a war going on inside a city somewhere. I'm sure if I devoted my time in reading all of the background articles the game wants you to spend reading I could of gleaned additional information, but I bought this game to be entertained via cinematics and gameplay. I did not want to be informed of key elements of the story via stopping game play to look up the excessive amounts of datalog files...\nAll things considered I found this to be the first Final Fantasy game I've played that was not enjoyable. After two hours of time I've given up on both this game and its sequel that I bought.

reviewText:
Aah~~ FFXIII.....the game everyone either loves or hates.
This game is definitely not for everyone, however you should still enjoy it if you're a huge FF fan.
The game is hugely linear,especially the first 20~30 hours,however the game does open up a little towards the end,though not by much. If you know you're not the kind of person that can handle linearity, do not pick up this title. The game has 13 Chapters, however the game only opens up at Chapter 11. Chapter 1~10 is all about getting used to the battle system and all about the storytelling.The world is really greatly thought out with some really great visuals. Masahi Hamauzu also did a great job with the soundtracks, following in the footsteps of Nobuo Uematsu.The soundtrack is simply awesome.
The story and characters are basically FF. Many people say the story is too convoluted, however if you follow the game's pacing everything will be handed on a plate, overall not a bad storyline.The characters are quite interesting and there are rooms for character development.
The battle system is quite different in a way it is really fast and frantic. It would seem like full-on buttle mashing but it has a lot of interesting approaches to a battle.The battle system is still a love or hate relationship, if you're considering this title, check up some gameplay on the Internet first.
Overall, I do enjoy this title and will recommend it to diehard FF fans. For gamers new to the series however, I strongly advise you to do extensive research before picking up. The game is still great but it may not be your taste. You have been warned.

reviewText:
First for those that HAVE played the game before, the game is 60gb of awful as a straight port.  That said, the game looks amazing with the Durante fix that I'm sure you can find easily by googling.  FPS suffers a bit but not much with the patch, but does drop every now and then, but not enough to ruin the experience (for me at least).   Also, just to put this out there, the alt-tab issue is fixed with the patch, the steam overlay seems to slow down significantly, and hitting escape will still exit the game immediately.

For those that HAVEN'T played the game before, DO NOT BUY THIS IF YOU'RE LOOKING FOR AN RPG.  Exploration is near non-existent, you have only a slight choice in building your characters, and during the 'tutorial' that lasts what seems like half the game, you don't even have control over your party as a whole.  There's only slight differences in the stats and abilities of all characters that you will have control over once everyone is fully built.

On the good side, however, i really enjoy the music and gameplay.   This is one of my favorite FF piano soundtracks, and even though it's not a true RPG, the gameplay is fast paced and does require a small degree of strategy (a little more so on the 'bosses').  The graphics deserve special mention as they are amazing.  Once again, you realy need the fix because the default steam version looks AWFUL compared to even the xbox's version.  And the story... oh the story... It has so much potential and is just a convoluted mess.   And don't get me started on the characters.  This may be a shoo-in for having at least some of the most shallow FF characters of all time, and easily has one of the most annoying.

So do I recommend it? Yep.  Just make sure you know what you're getting yourself into though!

reviewText:
Note: This review is updated to take the recently added graphic options into account.

I'll start with the port before moving to my opinion about the game itself (which I for some idiotic reason 100% completed).

PC port:

Graphic options:
The recent patch added graphic options to the game, which include
-Custom resolutions (up to 1080p (+?))
-MSAA Anti-aliasing (up to x16)
-Shadow resolutions (up to 8192 x 8192)
-(and full-screen/windowed mode)
So yeah, it's better than nothing, but it's not exactly amazing. Options are also changed in the launcher, which means that you can't change them in the game. The game runs at 60fps.
(It might be that the resolution goes higher than 1080p and it just doesn't show them to me because I have a 1080p monitor. Let me know if this is the case.)

Performance is poor, as a result of very poor PC optimization. Some people have reported that they are running this with smooth 60fps, but other people have reported huge performance issues even with high-end machines. I myself am getting around 30fps. What seems to be causing this is the UI, which is in some way bugged, and disabling the UI via a thirdy party program actually gives me a huge performance increase. However, you obviously can't play the game without the UI. This is something that Square should really look in to and fix it. FFXIII is not an action game so I found that bareable, but your opinion (and performance) may vary. I'd never play an action focused game at 30fps.

There is still no audio options, which is a problem for some people. There's also both Japanese and English audio, although this heavily increases the file size.
The game is roughly 50gb, so that might a problem for you if you have a small hard-drive or a slow internet connection.

Keyboard and mouse controls are functionable, although I found playing with a controller much more pleasant.
Keyboard and mouse controls are mostly rebindable. Mostly. You can't rebind movement controls from WASD (or whatever AZERTY uses) and selection keys, which are left and right mouse buttons. I really don't see this as a problem because, honestly, would you actually ever rebind those? Rest of the keys are fully rebindable.

So yeah, the port is still very barebones, but if you can deal with that, I think that the game is worth playing.

Review of the actual game:

Final Fantasy XIII is a very story focused game, so if this is not what you are looking for, I wouldn't recommend the game for you. First eleven chapters of the game are very linear, but this allowed them to focus on the story telling in a way that would not have been possible on a more open game, although at times even I found this linearity fairly dull. I actually quite enjoyed the story of the game.

I have one problem with the characters though. In my opinion, Final Fantasy XIII has five well written characters, and then there is Lightning. I just found her incredibly boring character, and aside from one scene in around chapter 4 or something with Hope, she received practically zero character development. This would not be a huge problem if she wouldn't happen to also be the main character of the game. On the other hand, I found all the other characters very well written.

Combat system of the game is fairly unique, and while it starts out as very repetitive, I did find it quite interesting after a while. Although I must recommend that do not use Auto-Battle" button. Just don't

Where do i begin with Final Fantasy XIII?

This game gives a very love hate relationship. I'll try my best to split the good and bad because i find it easier to point out the bad rather than what i actually like/love about this game. (SPOILERS AHEAD)


Good:

-Square Enix hardley ever dissapoint when it comes to delievering a lore and setting for a Final Fantasy title. The whole L'cie concept and how it can result is to me, original. The design of Cocoon and Gran Pulse feel very natural with the story arch alongside the whole Fal'cie and L'cie idea.

-Music. Now this i can say whole heartedly that Square Enix NEVER dissapoint when it comes to scoring a Final Fantasy game. If i were to give you a taste of why i think it's amazing then listen to this song.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D4ytiqB6xlU
The music in every big Final Fantasy title always make the lore feel very alive and rich, this part of the series that we all know and love is fortunately carried through in this title and i'm sure you'll all enjoy it.

-Game length. While i have 102 hours on my record i truly completed the game in 83 hours and the rest is where i left the game on and fell asleep but Final Fantasy only tracks time i've been actually playing. Final Fantasy is never usually a short game, especially because these titles are in development for many, many years. Don't worry about not thinking you might not get your money's worth out of this game because trust me, you will and there's still another 2 titles ahead of this that you have to play still.

-For the overall goodside i'm still not sure on what makes me love this game even with all of it's flaws (which i state below). I think the character i love the most is Sazh, he's the one who seems like he's the only one who's slightly true to the objective of the game. reviewText:
Final Hallway XIII - The greatest casual auto-pilot JRPG in the entire Final Fantasy library.

Well this game is a million years old now [obvious hyperbole]... let's talk about it.

On to the game play:

The first 20-25 hours of the game, depending on how much you love upgrading weapons and accessories, is basically a tutorial that eases you in to the battle system and crafting features.... Once you realize how easy it is, you'll wonder why they even bothered pacing you.

It's a FF game catering to mainstream JRPG casuals, just like FFX did years before it... flash some graphical T & A and the bro's come a running. Then they claim to think they know stuff about RPG's and believe they're diverse because they're playing a game outside of their realm of EA sports titles... *sigh* whatever... let them have their piece of candy.

This game basically combines the story telling and gameplay progression elements of Final Fantasy IV and the graphical boner inducing glory that was FFX, put them both in a blender and yeah, you get this... a great looking FF game with autism.

For the first 25 hours or so you are introducted to our motley crew of characters, their backgrounds, obnoxious personalities and how to set the game on auto-battle and leave it there until you gain some kind of control over your party.

The game also introduces the crafting system, albiet a bit briefly and never really explains much other than telling you that you can upgrade your gear and dismantle it or sell it for gil... Bringing me to my next gripe, you never earn gil in this game, only components and computer parts that you can sell for gil... kind of ridiculous in a FF title, no? So needless to say this game is artificially extended by the GRIND. Seriously the game is only about 50 hours long but you'll be grinding materials for over 80+ hours if you expect to get everything in the game maxed out... be warned.

The game's maps consist of linear hallways for roughly 80% of the game with only a few area's giving you some room to explore. Nothing is really hidden either, there are literally zero secrets in this game, everything is incredibly obvious and in your face. The map never lies to you either, every area is mapped out properly so once you hit the edge of a map, that's it... there are no hidden path ways... It doesn't leave much to the imagination unfortunately but at least you know you're not going to need a guide book to hit 100% completion.

FF13 sets out to tell a story, and that's exactly what it does, it's like the Metal Gear Solid 2 of Final Fantasy games... The game consists of very little game play and mostly cutscenes moving along the drama and unfolding the convoluted and confusing plot. At some point you'll just start disregarding everything everyone is saying so you can auto battle the next colossal, gorgeously rendered monster.

It's a great looking game, I'll give it that, it's just not a great Final Fantasy title... they stopped being great after FF6... it's just a sad fact. They all have way to many flaws in them to be considered great additions to the franchise and this is just another one added in to the mix of mixed bag RPG titles. Although I must admit, after playing FFXIII-2... it makes this game seem incredible in comparison.

I recommend this game for someone looking for a story to just disappear in to for a few hours a day but as a gamer who enjoys to actually play their games and delve in to things rather than just run back and forth grinding out materials... I'd have to say meh.

Thankfully I've already beaten this game years ago and felt like experiencing it again, so I'm in a good mood... other wise I would of just trashed it but in retrospect the game does look beautiful... and I think that's what SquareEnix's original intensions were... to just show case how powerful the new generation of consoles could be.

Either way, bad ports" aside (what did you expect? I mean really?) It's like a 6.5/10 overall."

reviewText:
The world of Final Fantasy XIII is stunning. Sadly, we don't get to see enough of it. Calling XIII linear would be an understatement.
The game has a deep story with some really interesting characters, watching these characters develop as the story progresses is what Final Fantasy is all about. XIII doesn't fall short in this area.

The Visuals and the musical score are beautiful as always, it's a Final Fantasy game after all. For a game released in 2014, the visuals hold up very well against games in 2016.

The Crystarium levelling system, while also beautiful to look at, again feels linear. Another sucker punch to the hardcore Final Fantasy fans like myself, is the inability to power level. The Crystarium system locks to each section of the story and puts a halt to over levelling your party.

I absolutely recommend FFXIII to hardcore Final Fantasy fans and users that are entirely new to the franchise.
A fantastic game yes, but a fantastic Final Fantasy game?

reviewText:
So after buying and finally completing this game, I've felt compelled to write a review on it.

A little preface about me, I've never played a single Final Fantasy game before, and lucky for me I went into this game without any sort of reference for comparison or expectation, besides the popularity and reputation. That being said, I played this game with an open mind and optimism.

To keep it short, the quantity of Pros I can list is more than the Cons, however the magnitude of those Cons I've seen puts my feelings towards it in a delicate balance.

The factors I believe favour this game are :
+great soundtrack
+memorable characters and their designs
+battle system
+difficulty
+well written story
+lovely visuals

That being said, the factors which oppose them are :
-level caps
-linearity
-sudden spikes in difficulty curve

But the one that stood out to me the most was the glaring fact that everything which pieces the game together is more or less good except for the GAMEPLAY itself. The factors which were supposed to make this game good didn't mesh or merge together at all. Everything felt too disjointed, and this left me largely unsatisfied. I'm sure this game had a lot of potential on the drawing boards, even now I can see that it does, but they really sacrificed quality gameplay, possibly overthinking that the components were enough. That doesn't work in a JRPG. I do admit that I did feel a lot of love and immersion during the cut-scenes, however that did not make up for the entire thing.

Looking at it now, the game in its rawest form is very good. If you're a fan of the series or a JRPG fan at heart I recommend it. Ibidem if you're an achievement hunter, though I do suggest possibly getting a trainer if you're in it just for the achievements, the game gets pretty hard and drawn out at its cusp. Highly recommend following a walkthrough either way.

To conclude, if you're familiar to RPG's and like how this game looks, or you bought it for cheap during Steam sales, give it a run through, you'll eventually at least want to continue on for the pretty stuff. However, if you're looking to get into JRPG's like Final Fantasy or never played a JRPG before, stay as FAR away from here as possible.
While I don't like to work on a number or rating system, I'll simply say I'm neutral to this game; it's okay. Not bad or great, just good. 7/10 from me.

reviewText:
I will start off by saying that I used to be a big fan of the FF series and Square's JRPGS of the 90's in general. After Squares PS1 era, I never had the chance or interest in playing any of the later installments in the FF series, mainly because I was exclusively a PC gamer. Then one day I notice to my surprise that they've released this on Steam, so I figured I'd go ahead and try the latest game in the series that I used to be such a big fan of in the past.

At first I have to comment on filesize of the game. When installed, the game takes 58 gb's of HDD which is insane!
The filesize is that big because the game includes both Japanese and English audio in the game and in the cutscene videos. It really would of been a nice if the original Japanese audio/video was an optional download. That way you would save up about 20gb worth of download time.

Now for the actual game:

Gameplay:
I found the gameplay incredibly boring and repetive. It doesn't have the ATB turn based combat of the previous installments, which I was aware of before I bought this game. Instead it has sort of real-time battle system where you only control one character. You can perform 3 moves in 1 turn and sort of chain different abilities and spells together. Or alternatively, you can just hit the auto-battle and it will automatically choose the best chains for you.
Seriously, every battle is the same: Auto battle -> Auto battle -> Auto battle -> Heal -> Auto battle -> Auto battle -> Auto battle ->

You can unlock new abilities and attributes for your characters with the Paradigms. Basically, your characters have these roles you can choose for them which include offensive, defensive and healing roles. Each of these roles have their own skill tree" which you can climb to unlock more abilities. The skill tree is as linear as it can get
date:
so theres no actual options to choose from at all. You will simply unlock everything in one order over time. You can also change these roles in combat at anytime when you need to go from doing damage to healing. Its also good to point out that you can't change roles for individual characters in battle.

The game doesn't really have any actual RPG depth to it at all. Theres only 2 different stats (Strength and Magic) and only 2 different types of items that you can equip (Weapon and accessory). Can't get much more simplified than that.

As for the difficulty of the game. Theres two settings
recommended: easy and normal. I played the game on normal and thought it was incredibly easy. None of the boss battles gave me any challenge whatsoever (but then again
hoursPlayed:
how could it with such a simplified gameplay mechanics). The game also recharges your health back to full everytime you win a abttle.

Graphics:
The graphics are quite alright. The game is about 4-5 years old with initial release on 360 and PS3
voteText: so you can't realistically expect anything spectacular. Now that SquareEnix actually managed to get the game to run at 1080p

reviewText:
This is my first time playing through Final Fantasy XIII and 8 hours in I'm satisfied so far. The combat system is new, the roles have names I'm not used to, but you adjust quickly and figure it out as you go. I was fully prepared for the linear aspect of the game and with all the cutscenes I am choosing to view my playthrough as a long movie with some battle sequences thrown in. I bought this game to experience the story so I am fine with this.

Prepare for a long download! This game comes in at a whopping 50GB. I was expecting to play the night I purchased it but wasn't finished with the download until noon the following morning.

In terms of bugs and glitches, I'm assuming the November update made some big changes because I am having 0 issues with the game so far. I will update my review if something comes up but having played for a few days I am content with the quality of this port. I'll definitely be buying a copy of XIII-2.

reviewText:
Amazing :)
Never thought this would be on PC, the graphics in full 1080p resolution are beautiful. I definitely felt a bit of nostalgia, even though this game is only 4 years old.

I've beaten it twice, and completed most end-game content on the Xbox 360, and looking forward to completing it a 3rd time.

Negatives from launch:
- No settings for PC, and no 1080p support (which I had to fix with something called GeDoSaTo which was easy to setup)
- Combat is simplified for the majority of the game. (most of the time you can just press A to auto-battle)
- Story is somewhat cryptic, and hard to follow at times.
- Some of the characters can be annoying (Hope...)

Otherwise, it's a very visually appealing game, with some great bosses, and a fluid fast paced combat system. If you are a fan of Final Fantasy, or just looking for some sweet eye-candy I'd definitely reccomend this game.

reviewText: Having felt great excitement over the news of the PC port I found myself rather dissapointed at the effort put into the final product. Having recently played another console-born game brought into the realm of PC gaming, Valkyria Chronicles, I was astonished at how badly Square Enix has adapted this game for PC. The UI in particular is a hassle (esc quits the game instantly? Seriously??? Who the ♥♥♥♥ thought that would be a sensible idea????? (also the time for them to fix this and the quality of the fix itself are rather pathetic to say the least)). Don't get me wrong, the game's fantastic and I could not recommend it more if its interface was not copy&pasted from the console versions, but in the current state I found the game rather hard to enjoy. The very fact that some talented modders have already provided 3rd party applications to resolve some of these issues clearly highlight the sad truth that currently, Square Enix is simply not very devoted in bringing this franchise to the PC.

reviewText:
The Game
Having played every Final Fantasy game since the start of the franchise I was excited to finally play FFXIII without purchasing a console. My impressions of the game itself are mixed but positive. Character development is phenomenal and the story is engaging. I would have been happy watching the first 10 chapters (instead of playing them). The paradigm system relies significantly on switching AI profiles to manage combat. While it takes away some strategy, combat is nevertheless fast-paced and engaging.


The few low points are the extreme linearity of most of the story, slow then sudden character progression, and upgrade system. For much of the game you literally walk characters down hallways. Then, quite suddently, you are thrust into an expansive overworld! Character progression is slow and boring, but eases you into many of the non-obvious game mechanics. Upgrading weapons and accessories is pointless through most of the game, then only crucial post-game (apparently...).

The Port
Here is why I would never recommend this game: the port is terrible. I've stuggled through 30 hours of gameplay and have can no longer tolerate the laggy and stuttering graphics. My computer exceeds the recommend requirements (AMD Phenom X4 965 and AMD Radeon 6850) but still struggles to plan the game at 720p. I have spent hours going through every possible fix" to similar problems and nothing works or even improves performance. I quit."

reviewText: I'm going to write a review about how Final Fantasy XIII, but keep in mind I will ignore the well known performance issues because they will be fixed by December and it's not worth rating down a game entirely just because of its performance problems.Let me say first of all that I've been excited about its release on PC for a very long time and I couldn't be happier when I released it's on Steam finally.The performance problems didn't make the game less enjoyable for me because I've seen worse type of problems but I'm sure it made many other people used to constant 60 fps.Anyway to start,the graphics are amazing for its requirements,the game itself as everyone knows is locked in 1280x720 resolution but  a modder created a tool called Gedosado which scales the game to up to 1080p or even 4k, even though the tool needs some work it's enough to make the game playable in high resolution until Square Enix patches the game.You'll get carried away in the game's story:the entire time that I've played the game it felt like I was in a movie (firstly because the cutscenes added up are around 8 hours),so that idea made it exciting,what will happen next?The story has a little bit of everything in it:action,drama,romance,comedy,mystery and as you progress through the game the story deepens and you'll find yourself caught up in it,you'll want to know more about each character and how they can change their fate.The soundtrack isn't less amazing than the rest,perfectly orchestrated you will fight each battle with more eagerness and you will sometimes want to enter a fight (even though not necessary) just to listen to the music again.The characters themselves have a very unique personality and as the story progress they become better people,learning from their past mistakes,it's hard to pick a favorite because in the end you'll like something about each of them but it's them as a team that you'll love the most.Although you might find Vanille a bit stressful sometimes when she has too much optimism but who wouldn't want to be like her in daily life too?The most important aspect is the gameplay and it's what gives the game its name,it's identity.You could say the game is a real time turn based rpg.It will feel too easy at the beginning of the game and you'll feel like the game is for the novice gamers.Not at all,the beginning of the game just prepares you for the harder parts later in the game which I might say are almost impossible even on the easy difficulty.The bad thing about the gameplay is that it's linear,even though the environment is big,it's not an open world game but it almost feels like it.Things are pretty straight forward from the beginning to the end of the game but it doesn't make the game less fun if you consider all the other good things about it.From my point of view it's worth buying and it's not even too expensive.Do not let the entirely negative reviews about it stop you from playing it .The problems will be solved as I said above and even with the current issues the game is still playable.Hope this review helped,enjoy the game if you intend to buy it!

reviewText:
If you like looking at corridors, this game's for you. People complain about the linearity of FFXIII but I put it to them that most of the FF games are just as linear and that works just fine for them.

If you like Final Fantasy games, you'll like this one. If you're getting in to them, I'd start at something like 10 instead (maybe the HD port will come to Steam one day!). If you don't like them, well, why are you reading this review, this game is obviously not for you. :P

The scenery is beautiful, the gameplay is fun - even on easy bosses can be quite a challenge so make sure you have the right paradigms set up so you can switch to either aggression or healing whenever you need. Vanille's voice slips all over the world in terms of accent but as a bright and cheerful character she's a ray of light in the first 15 or so hours of the game.

I'm about 17 hours in to the game at time of writing and I've only just been given the ability to change my party members - since it apparently takes that long to get the party together and for most of the game you're jumping between pre-determined groups. Which is fine for plot reasons though it is really nice to actually have a say in who I'm playing as. Not expecting too much from the plot, it's certainly not 13's most redeeming quality. But it's a fun game - especially if you just want to relax - I find this is the game I turn to when I want to mostly switch my brain off. Which isn't a criticism - it's good to relax with video games and the gorgeous scenery and indeed the game's contentious linearity are absolutely perfect for that.

reviewText: Final Fantasy XIII is not an usual open-world jrpg like past titles, however the story (which is always the backbone of every Final Fantasy) is no less stunning and original. The design and atmosphere of both shining utopian world of Cocoon and wild, dangerous and abandoned Gran Pulse is just so original, you will never know where to look first. Although the visual side of the game was apparently top priority for developers, all of the other aspects are not so bad as people like to claim. All of the characters have their own motivations and troubles, and even though i didn't enjoy unfolding their stories as much as i did in Final Fantasy VII, or Final Fantasy IX, it was in no way boring.\n\nFrom very start of the game, you must forget about how our world works and patiently absorb the atmosphere and working of Fabula Nova Crystalis universe. There is no explanatory intro and you are thrown into conflict between two sides you don't know, in place you don't recognize on a planet which is apparently freaking inverted (reminded me of standing on the inside of Halo ring). It comes slowly and I spent a LOT of time browsing through datalog" (kind of in-game encyclopedia and journal) so the mild feeling of confusion is something you should expect from the beginning. I personally enjoyed the slow exploration of this strange sci-fi
recommended: mythical world however.\n\nThe combat in XIII is an interesting mix of direct action (your character) and indirect role selecting (two other characters in your party) which makes for a lot of ways to play. Just look at youtube and you will find that everyone uses quite different team compositions. Generally the combat is fast
